LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Socialist Republic of Viet Nam 
   
Classification  Targeting  classification:  Targeted  intervention  (Millennium 
Development Goals [TI-M]). 
Sector  (subsector):  Water  supply  and  other  municipal 
infrastructure and services (water supply and sanitation) 
Themes  (subthemes):  Social  development  (human 
development), gender equity (human capabilities) 
Location impact: rural (high) 
   
Environment  The  environmental  classification  of  the  project  is  category  B. 
Assessment  Based on the results of initial environmental examinations, the 
subprojects  are  unlikely  to  cause  significant  adverse 
environmental impacts. They are intended to improve the quality 
of the environment and the living standards of rural communities. 
The benefits of the subprojects include an increase in the number 
of houses connected to clean and reliable water for drinking and 
sanitation, a reduction in or elimination of flooding and stagnation 
of  wastewater,  and  better  personal  sanitation.  The  potential 
adverse  environmental  impacts  associated  with  design, 
construction, and operation of the subprojects will mostly be small 
and  localized  and  can  be  readily  mitigated  through  proper 
engineering  design  and  implementation  of  the  mitigation  and 
monitoring  measures  identified  in  the  initial  environmental 
examinations.  An  environmental  assessment  and  review 
framework has been prepared for future subprojects. 
   
Project Description  The project will increase access to water supply and sanitation, 
improving the health and quality of life of the rural population in six 
selected provinces in the central coastal region of Viet Nam. The 
project  will  support  the  government  in  implementing  its 
Socioeconomic  Development  Plan,  2006–2010,  including 
reducing  poverty  to  10%–11%  of  households  by  2010.  In  so 
doing,  it  will  help  the  government  to  achieve  the  Vietnamese 
Millennium Development Goals.  
 
The project will provide piped water and hygienic sanitation to 
about  350,000  people  living  in  rural  areas.  The  project  has  a 
strong poverty focus and its design is based on lessons from 
previous interventions in the sector. The implementation will follow 
a  community-based  approach  and  will  focus  on  (i)  improving 
hygienic behavior, (ii) strengthening operation and maintenance of 
the water supply works, and (iii) monitoring and evaluation of the 
outputs  and  impacts  of  rural  water  supply  and  sanitation 
investments.

ii   
Rationale  In  2006,  about  46%  of  the  rural  population  of  Viet  Nam  had 
access to clean water, although at quantities barely sufficient to 
support their basic needs and not continuously throughout the 
year. About 83% of the population had latrines, but only 48% of 
these  could  be  considered  hygienic.  About  37%  of  the  rural 
population still practiced open defecation. In 2006, about 72% of 
public schools had latrines but only 12% of them were hygienic. 
Only 21% of commune health centers had latrines.  
 
Knowledge of individual sanitation was still poor. In 2006 only 
2.3% of the rural population knew that hand washing with soap 
may  prevent  some  communicable  diseases,  and  only  13%  of 
households and 11% of the students washed their hands with 
soap before meals and after urination or defecation.  
 
Better access to clean water and hygienic sanitation will improve 
public health. This in turn will reduce poverty by reducing medical 
expenses and productive days lost. In addition, the project will 
also reduce the burden on woman and girls, who are traditionally 
tasked with water collection and caring for sick family members. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The  impact  of  the  project  will  be  improved  health  and  living 
conditions of people living in rural areas in the project provinces. 
The project will contribute to the National Rural Water Supply and 
Sanitation Strategy to 2020, which states that, by 2020, 100% of 
the rural population will (i) have access to clean water, with a 
minimum volume of 60 liters per capita per day, (ii) use hygienic 
latrines, and (iii) practice proper personal hygiene. 
 
The outcome will be access to clean water and hygienic sanitation 
for  about  350,000  people  living  in  rural  areas  in  about  30 
communes  in  the  six  project  provinces  in  the  central  coastal 
region of Viet Nam: Binh Dinh, Ha Tinh, Nghe An, Quang Binh, 
Quang Nam, and Thanh Hoa.

including taxes and duties of $4.4 million.

Implementation  A central project management unit will be established within the 
Arrangements  National Center for Rural Water Supply and Sanitation of MARD 
to coordinate project implementation. The provincial Departments 
of  Agriculture  and  Rural  Development  will  set  up  a  provincial 
project  management  unit.  The  provincial  Viet  Nam  women’s 
unions will be responsible for managing the revolving funds for 
sanitation  improvement.  At  the  commune  level,  water  and 
sanitation commune committees will be established and sanitation 
and health promoters identified to ensure community participation 
in  project  implementation  and  implement  hygiene  awareness 
activities. 
   
Procurement  Goods, works, and services financed by the Asian Development 
Bank  (ADB)  will  be  procured  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). All 
procurement  contracts  will  contain  anticorruption  provisions  as 
specified by ADB. Procurement will generally be carried out by the 
PPMUs and supported by the international consultant. Civil works 
above  $2,000,000  or  goods  above  $500,000  will  be  procured 
through international competitive bidding. Civil works with value of 
$2,000,000 or less and goods with value of $500,000 or less, will 
be procured through national competitive bidding. Civil works and 
goods with value of $100,000 or less will be procured through 
shopping. Civil works contracts for household sanitation with a 
total value of $5,000 or less can be procured at the commune 
level and will follow community participation in procurement in 
accordance  with  ADB's  procedures  for  implementing  small 
projects with community participation.  
   
Consulting Services  Consultants will be recruited in line with ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use  of  Consultants  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
Consulting services will include the following packages: (i) general 
project  management;  (ii)  technical  design  and  procurement 
services; (iii) preparation of safeguard documents; (iv) community 
mobilization  and  information,  education,  and  communication 
implementation; and (v) capacity building of water supply system 
operators.  Consulting  firms  will  be  recruited  to  provide  these 
services, at a total of 1,497 person-months, of which 285 person-
months  will  be  for  international  specialists  and  1,212  person-
months for national specialists. The consulting services will be 
acquired through the quality- and cost-based selection method. 
The technical proposals will be given a weight of 80% and the 
financial proposals 20%. ADB's Procurement Guidelines will be 
applicable  throughout  the  consulting  services.  The  assets 
purchased will be handed over to MARD upon completion of the

ADB's management has approved advance recruitment of consulting 
services. The government has been advised that approval of the 
advance action and retroactive financing does not commit ADB to 
finance the project, and that the action should be carried out in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. 
   
Project Benefits and  In the subproject areas, all the households will be provided with 
Beneficiaries  clean water and sanitation services in an equitable and affordable 
manner.  The  project  will  provide  access  to  clean  water  and 
hygiene  sanitation  facilities  to  approximately  350,000  people, 
about 27% of whom live in poverty, compared with 16% in Viet 
Nam as a whole. Access to clean water and sanitation at the 
household level is expected to improve public health, especially 
child health, and to reduce medical expenditure. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  The potential risks are: (i) poor households may not be able to 
afford water tariffs that will provide full cost recovery; (ii) local 
government agencies may not be able to implement community-
based approaches and gender strategies, or may resist doing so; 
(iii) implementation of information, education, and communication 
materials may take a traditional top-down approach instead of 
intensive community mobilization; (iv) women, poor people, and 
members of ethnic minorities may be marginalized in the decision 
making  and  planning  of  water  and  sanitation  facilities  at  the 
community  level;  (v)  beneficiaries  may  not  adopt  hygienic 
behavior,  which  may  reduce  some  benefits  of  the  project; 
(vi) water supply facilities may not be sustainable because of low 
water  tariffs  and  improper  operation  and  maintenance.  Risk 
mitigation measures are integrated into the project design. 
 
The  main  assumptions  are  that  the  government  (i)  remains 
committed  to  the  rural  water  supply  sector  and  continues  to 
provide counterpart funding, (ii) is willing to learn from the lessons 
of previous interventions in the sector, and (iii) makes available 
sufficient staff for project planning and implementation at central 
and provincial level. It is furthermore assumed that all eligible 
communities  agree  to  actively  participate  in  project 
implementation.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Central Region Rural Water Supply and Sanitation 
Sector Project. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
2.  The project will contribute to the achievement of the key goals of the ADB country 
strategy  and  program  (CSP),1  2007−2010:  promoting  socially  equitable  and  balanced 
development,  sustainable  environmental  management,  and  stronger  institutions.  It  will  also 
support  the  major  targets  of  Viet  Nam’s  Socioeconomic  Development  Plan  (SEDP), 
2006−2010,2 including  reducing  the  poverty  rate  to  10%−11%.  Viet  Nam’s  average  gross 
domestic product growth of 7.8% per year between 2002 and 2007 reduced its overall poverty 
rate from 28.9% to 16.0%. However, the poverty rate in the rural areas (where 72% of the 
people live) is still 20.4%. The framework for all poverty reduction activities in Viet Nam is the 
Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy,3 which recognizes that access to 
clean and safe water and hygienic latrines4 is one of the preconditions for poverty reduction, 
particularly for Viet Nam's rural population.  
 
3.  In 2006, about 46% of the rural population had access to clean water, although at 
quantities barely sufficient to support basic needs and not continuously throughout the year. 
About 83% of the population had latrines, but only 48% of these could be considered hygienic. 
About 37% of the rural population still practiced open defecation. In 2006, about 72% of the 
public schools had latrines but only 12% of them were hygienic, while only 21% of commune 
health centers had latrines.  
 
4.  Knowledge of individual sanitation was still poor. In 2006 only 2.3% of rural population 
knew that hand washing with soap may prevent some communicative diseases, and only 13% 
of households and 11% of students washed their hands with soap before meals and after 
urination or defecation.  
 
5.  Better access to clean water and hygienic sanitation will improve public health. In turn, 
this will reduce poverty by reducing medical expenses and productive days lost. The burden on 
women and girls, who are traditionally tasked with water collection and caring for sick family 
members, will be reduced. 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
6.  Geographic focus.  The central coastal region of Viet Nam consists of 14 provinces and 
accounts for about 30% of the country's total land area. The population is predominantly rural 
(78%). The focus of the proposed project on this region is justified by its high poverty levels, low 
water supply and sanitation coverage, and the limited availability of suitable water resources.

9.  Low sanitation coverage. Table 3 indicates that open defecation is widely practiced in 
the central coastal provinces.  
 
10.  Drainage problems. The surface drainage facilities available in some communes are 
affected by a lack of proper facilities for gray wastewater and storm water. This leads to 
stagnant water pools, mosquito breeding, and flooding by contaminated water during rains. 
These problems are acute in the areas located in the coastal flat terrain, which have high 
groundwater tables. 
 
11.  Lack of exploitable water sources. The shallow groundwater layers in the central 
region contain high levels of salinity, turbidity, hardness, fluoride, iron, manganese, aluminum, 
and pollution from human, industrial, and livestock waste. Surface water is often of poor quality 
due to turbidity, organic matter, and pollution by surface runoff that contains micro-organisms 
and agricultural chemicals. The central coastal provinces have low amounts of exploitable 
groundwater, so many poor rural households use highly polluted water for their daily needs.

12.  Government strategy and investment plan. Government intervention in the rural water 
supply and sanitation (RWSS) sector began in 1999 with the development of a national RWSS 
strategy, which set ambitious coverage targets for 2010 (85% coverage for clean water supply 
and 70% for hygienic latrines) and 2020 (100% coverage for both clean water supply and 
hygienic latrines). At that time, less than 30% of the rural population had access to water that 
met  basic  hygienic  criteria,  and  less  than  20%  of  rural  households  had  hygienic  latrines. 
Investment in RWSS was only 10% of the amount needed, and the understanding of good 
hygienic  practices  was  low.  In  addition,  RWSS  programs  were  fragmented,  with  little 
coordination among ministries and departments, and the legislative environment was weak with 
respect to regulations and guidelines for managing the sector. A sector analysis is in Appendix 2 
and an overview of external assistance is in Appendix 3. 
 
13.  In developing the strategy, the importance of RWSS was recognized, as 75% of the 
national population lives in rural areas. In recognition of the importance of improving the RWSS 
sector, the government made it one of seven national target programs for the period 2001–2005 
(NTP I). An evaluation of NTP I in 2005 revealed that progress had been made5 and assumed 
that the water supply coverage targets for 2010 and 2020 would be met, provided current 
investment  levels  were  maintained.  For  sanitation,  however,  there  was  little  prospect  of 
achieving the planned targets, since the reliance on household finances to build latrines had 
caused coverage rates of the poor to lag far behind those of better-off households. The review 
also stressed the importance of targeting government and partner organization support at the 
poorest  populations,  specifically  in  coastal  areas,  where  population  density  is  high  and 
exploitable water supplies are limited. 
 
14.  A second national target program was approved in 2006, covering the period 2006–2010 
(NTP II), which addressed some of the issues identified in the evaluation of NTP I.6 NTP II

15.  Key sector institutions. The Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD) is 
responsible  for  implementing  the  RWWS  strategy  through  its  provincial  departments  of 
agriculture and rural development (DARDs). Under MARD is a National Center for Rural and 
Clean  Water  and  Environmental  Sanitation  (NCERWASS)  to  which  MARD  has  delegated 
responsibility for RWSS project implementation. At the provincial level, project implementation is 
delegated  by  DARDs  to  provincial  centers  for  rural  and  clean  water  and  environmental 
sanitation (PCERWASS). The Ministry of Health (MOH), General Department of Preventive 
Medicine and AIDS control is responsible for setting and monitoring drinking water quality 
standards and for developing public awareness of hygiene and health. The MOH works through 
its provincial departments of health (DOHs) and district and commune health care centers. The 
Ministry of Education and Training (MOET) is responsible for implementing school sanitation 
programs  through  its  provincial  departments  of  education  and  training  (DOETs).  In  2007, 
MARD, MOH, and MOET signed an interministerial circular on guidelines for implementing and 
coordinating  the  RWSS  strategy  among  the  three  ministries.  Information,  education,  and 
communication (IEC) guidelines issued by NCERWASS recognized the importance of commune 
committees and local health promoters in increasing awareness of sanitation and hygiene. Mass 
organizations, such as women’s unions, play important roles in community mobilization and 
initiating community-based savings or credit groups. 
 
16.  Country strategy and program. The current CSP for Viet Nam aims to support the

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
17.  Budget deficit. Continued support from partner organizations will be needed for the 
government to implement NTP II and achieve the targets set out in the RWSS strategy. This 
strategy expects an unrealistically high contribution by the beneficiaries to the total budget of 
61%. The budget calculations are based on assumed investment costs of $34 per capita for 
water supply and $20 per household for sanitation, which is considerably lower than commonly 
used unit prices.11 It is expected that the actual budget will be four to five times higher than this 
and  that  contributions  from  partner  organizations  eight  to  ten  times  higher  than  current 
estimates will be required. When it reviews the strategy, the government will address this issue 
by preparing a more detailed budget estimate and financing plan. Without increased support 
from partner organizations, the RWSS targets will not be achieved.   
 
18.  Need for piped water supply systems. The government has recognized the need for 
piped water supply systems to be constructed in areas where access to clean water sources is 
limited, because of the pollution of shallow groundwater and water scarcity. The RWSS strategy 
stresses the importance of promoting piped water supply systems, while the NTP II calls for the 
construction of 4,900 new piped water supply schemes nationwide. The government's policy is 
to provide these schemes without charge in areas where the population is predominantly poor, 
provided the systems will create sufficient revenues to be operated in a sustainable manner. 
 
19.  Limited focus on sanitation improvement. Sanitation has been widely neglected by 
the  existing  planning  and  implementation  system,  so  achievement  of  national  targets  on 
sanitation is behind schedule. In rural areas, sanitation is often limited to the construction of 
household  latrines,  normally  regarded  to  be  the  responsibility  of  households  themselves. 
Household, public and school latrine programs have received limited attention from political 
leaders. The project will support subprojects that include sanitation improvements as well as 
water supply.  
 
20.  Limited knowledge of the benefits of hygienic practices. Although the provision of 
latrines and sanitation infrastructure brings improved health and environmental outcomes, these 
are significantly increased when beneficiaries are exposed to IEC programs on household 
sanitation practices that improve their awareness of the relationship between water, sanitation, 
and hygiene. In addition, considerable health and environmental improvements can be achieved 
by providing public and school latrines and better drainage systems, all supported by specific 
IEC programs.  
 
21.  Many IEC materials have been developed in Viet Nam. Supported by various partner 
organizations, the government has made an inventory of the materials available, which have 
been evaluated and placed in the public domain for easy reference.12 In 2003, the government 
published  an  implementation  guideline  on  IEC,  introducing  the  concept  of  a  community 
responsive approach.13  
 
22.  The main lessons learned from previous IEC programs in Viet Nam are that (i) allocated 
budgets too small to implement complete IEC programs, including evaluation of impacts; (ii) IEC 
programs  are  implemented  on  a  short-term  basis  only  and  are  discontinued  following  the 
completion  of  construction  of  associated  works;  (iii)  IEC  programs  should  be  extended  to

23.  Insufficient  community  participation.  The  project  will  be  implemented  using  the

government approved a new monitoring and evaluation (M&E) program that includes eight

as  part  of  the  project  performance  management  system,  the  implementation  of  which  by 
provincial and district governments will be supported through a series of workshops.  
 
25.  Improved sustainability of water supply systems. The sustainability of water supply 
systems depends on effective operation and management of the system and the affordability 
and willingness of the beneficiaries to pay. The project will support intensive and continuous 
training of managers and operators of the water supply systems in setting water tariffs that are 
high enough to recover full costs, following the government's guidelines.15 However, the tariffs 
should be affordable and full cost recovery should not be an excuse for inefficient operation of 
the water supply system. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
26.  The impact of the project will be better health and living conditions of people living in 
rural areas in the project provinces. The project will contribute to the RWSS strategy, which 
states that, by 2020, 100% of the rural population will (i) have access to clean water, with a 
minimum volume of 60 liters per capita per day; (ii) use hygienic latrines; and (iii) practice proper 
personal hygiene. The project is designed as a sector investment project. It meets the criteria 
for sector lending since: (i) the RWSS strategy forms a solid basis for project implementation,  
(ii)  NCERWASS  has  proven  capacity  to  implement  RWSS  projects,  and  (iii)  the  policies 
applicable to the water and sanitation sector are appropriate. 
 
27.  The outcome will be access to clean water and hygienic sanitation for about 350,000 
rural people in about 30 communes in the six project provinces in the central coastal region of 
Viet Nam: Binh Dinh, Ha Tinh, Nghe An, Quang Binh, Quang Nam, and Thanh Hoa. The design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

28.  Selection of project provinces. The selection of the six project provinces was based 
on: (i) the poverty level, (ii) the size of the rural population, (iii) the number of rural residents with 
access to clean water and hygienic latrines, and (iv) the percentage of ethnic minorities. In 
addition to these quantifiable criteria, two more selection criteria were applied: (v) the access to 
suitable surface and shallow groundwater sources, and (vi) the capacity of local government to 
implement the proposed project. The six selected provinces have large poor rural populations 
and large ethnic minority populations.16  
 
29.  Subproject  selection.  The  project  design  is  based  on  a  detailed  analysis  of  six 
subprojects,  one  in  each  project  province.  The  subprojects  include  communes  that  are 
representative of others in terms of their socioeconomic profiles, water supply and sanitation 
needs, and projected impacts.  
 
30.  Each subproject will consist of one or more communities, covered by a single piped 
water supply system. Each system may cover 300−3,000 households or 1,500−18,000 people. 
Although classified as rural, the communities are relatively densely populated and are mostly 
situated  around  public  markets  and  along  provincial  roads.  The  subprojects  will  follow  an 
integrated  approach  to  the  improvement  of  water  supply  and  sanitation,  including  minor 
drainage improvement. The project will support a CBA, ensuring the active involvement of the 
communities in the preparation, planning, design, construction and operation of the water supply 
and sanitation facilities.  
 
31.  It  is  expected  that  six  to  nine subprojects  will  be selected  and  approved  annually. 
Approval of the subprojects will be based on a subproject appraisal report that includes (i) a 
feasibility study; (ii) required safeguard documents on the environment, resettlement, and ethnic 
minorities; (iii) a CBA-IEC plan; and (iv) a baseline survey covering socioeconomic, health, and 
water supply and sanitation coverage data. The capacity of the provinces to implement a 
subproject will be assessed by ADB, based on the progress made in implementing subprojects 
in the previous batch. Provinces that perform satisfactorily may be awarded more subprojects 
than provinces that perform poorly. Detailed selection criteria are in Appendix 4.

(ii)  tap  water  will  be  clean  and  safe  for  human  consumption  without  further  treatment;

average monthly income.

34.  The government follows six management models for rural water supply operations, of 
which four are considered to be suitable for piped water supply systems:19 (i) the cooperative 
management model, (ii) the PCERWASS management model, (iii) the private management 
model, and (iv) the enterprise management model. Viet Nam has limited experience of the 
management of rural water supply schemes by cooperatives, the private sector, or enterprises. 
Piped water supply systems are considered too complex to be managed by cooperatives, while 
no privately operated water supply systems have been identified in the project provinces. The 
World Bank promotes the enterprise model despite the absence of lessons to draw upon.20 The 
most common model is the PCERWASS model, whereby PCERWASS selects local people to 
train these into operators. This model has varying success rates, depending on the quality of 
training and educational background of the selected operators. The project will support the 
PCERWASS  management  model,  with  a  strong  emphasis  on  building  the  capacity  of  the 
management and operational staff, before and during system operations.

C.  Special Features 
50.  Poverty  focus. The project has a strong poverty focus: (i) subproject selection will 
prioritize communes with high poverty levels; (ii) house connections will be provided at minimum 
cost,28 allowing  poor  families  to  benefit  equally  from  the  water  supply  services  provided;  
(iii) poor households29 will be eligible for grants to construct sanitation facilities; and (iv) the IEC 
program will be implemented through CBA, encouraging poor households to participate. 
 
51.  Integrated  approach  to  water  supply,  sanitation,  and  hygiene  promotion.  The 
benefits from access to improved water supply and sanitation infrastructure will be strengthened 
if  behavioral  change  leads  to  improved  hygienic  practices.  The  project  will  only  support 
subprojects that include investments in infrastructure and behavioral change programs. The 
project will support school sanitation programs, since children often educate their parents in 
proper hygiene practices.   
 
52.  Community-based approach to subproject implementation. To prevent communities 
returning  to  their  traditional  practices  following  project  completion,  the  subprojects  will  
(i)  address  community  needs,  (ii)  provide  services,  and  (iii)  remain  affordable  to  the  poor 
households.  The  project  supports  (i)  capacity  building  and  awareness-raising  of  local 
communities,  (ii)  participatory  decision  making  on  communities'  involvement  in  project 
implementation and IEC, (iii) community-based procurement of small sanitation works to meet 
local needs, and (iv) capacity building of government and mass organizations to create an 
enabling environment and strengthen governance relationships. 
 
53.  Information,  education,  and  communication  as  a  continuing  activity. Sustained 
behavioral change can only be achieved through long-term support. The project will support IEC 
activities on a continuing basis starting immediately after approval of the subprojects until 6 
months after completion of the construction works. The total duration of the IEC support will be 
3–3.5 years.

F.  Implementation Arrangements 
1.  Project Management 
56.  MARD will be the executing agency of the project. A central project management unit 
(CPMU)  will  be  established  within  the  NCERWASS  of  MARD  to  coordinate  project 
implementation.  The  CPMU  will  (i)  provide  technical  support  for  project  implementation, 
supervision  and  training  to  the  project  provinces  through  project  consultants;  (ii)  make 
withdrawal applications to ADB for disbursement of the loan proceeds; (iii) monitor withdrawals 
by  the  PPMUs  from  the  SGIAs;  (iv)  review,  and  submit  project  financial  reports  from  the 
provincial level; (v) review the project performance monitoring data; (vi) recruit an independent 
auditor and ensure that periodic project audits are properly carried out in a timely manner; (vii) 
coordinate  all  reporting  activities,  consolidate  reports  and  ensure  timely  submission  of 
semiannual  reports  to  MARD  and  ADB;  (viii)  monitor  and  coordinate  all  project-related 
procurement to ensure compliance with the requirements of the Borrower and ADB.; and (ix) act 
as liaison between the government and ADB. 
 
57.  The PPCs shall be responsible for carrying out the project at the provincial level.  DARD 
is  responsible  for  implementing  the  subprojects  and  shall  set  up  a  PPMU  within  the 
PCERWASS of the project provinces. Each PPMU shall consist of experienced professional 
staff from at least the relevant units within PCERWASS and a representative of the subproject 
CPC. The PPMU shall be responsible for: (i) liaising with the CPMU, other PPMUs and CPCs; 
(ii) selecting and proposing subprojects; (iii) carrying out subproject feasibilities studies and 
preparing  subproject  feasibility  reports  that  will  include  technical  design,  appraisal,  bidding 
documents for civil works and safeguards reports; (iv) procuring civil works; (v) establishing a 
procurement  committee,  chaired  by  the  PCERWASS  director; 33 (vi)  implementing  land 
acquisition, resettlement, environmental, ethnic minorities and gender activities; (vii) providing 
technical advice to communities on the development of water supply and sanitation facilities and 
their subsequent O&M; (viii) implementing an awareness campaign on water use, sanitation, 
and hygiene; (ix) collecting M&E data and entry to computerized database; and (x) preparing 
reports.  
 
58.  The  PVWUs  will  be  responsible  for  implementing  the  revolving  funds  for sanitation 
improvement. Through the commune VWUs, the PVWUs will promote public awareness of the 
credit scheme, identify poor households, process credit applications, channel payments and 
collect  repayment,  maintain  accounts  and  records,  and  inspect  and  certify  credit-funded 
infrastructure. The PPMU will have overall responsibility for the implementation of activities at 
the subproject level and will be accountable for all related expenditure, including revolving funds 
and community funds. The accounts of the credit scheme will be subject to audit by the project 
auditor recruited by the CPMU. The required legal documents and detailed implementation and 
monitoring guidelines will be prepared by the consultants. The implementation arrangements

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
74.  Poverty and social impacts. About 27% of the population of the central coastal region 
lived in poverty in 2006, compared with 16% in Viet Nam as a whole. The monthly per capita 
income was lower than the national average. About 70% of the population lives in rural areas. In 
the subproject areas, 44% of the labor force is engaged in agriculture and the poverty rate 
ranges from 15.5% to 34.5%. 
 
75.  Equitable access to clean and affordable water continues to be a critical issue in rural 
areas of Viet Nam. In the subproject areas, all households will be provided with clean water and 
sanitation  services  in  an  equitable  and  affordable  manner.  The  project  will  provide 
approximately 350,000 people with access to clean water and hygienic sanitation facilities. 
Access to clean water and sanitation by households will improve public health, especially child 
health, and will reduce medical expenditures. By targeting remote rural areas, the project will 
benefit populations with high poverty levels.  
 
76.  Ethnic minorities. The number of ethnic groups in the project provinces varies from 3 to 
28. The groups include the Ba-na, Bru-van-kieu, Ca Rai, Cham, Chut, Co Tu, Edo Nagi, Gia 
Rai, Gie Trieng, Hoa, Khemer, Moung, Nung, Tay, Thai,  Tho Dao, and, Xe Dang.  However, the 
percentage of ethnic minority people in the project provinces is relatively small (ranging from 2% 
to 14%), except for the subproject area of Quang Nam Province, which has a population that is 
80% Co Tu and a poverty rate of 60%.  
 
77.  The  ethnic  minorities  in  the  project  provinces  are  integrated  into  the  mainstream 
population in terms of language, schooling, and clothing. The subprojects will not have any 
adverse cultural effects on these groups. The ethnic minority people will benefit from both the 
water and the sanitation services provided by the project. To ensure that ethnic minority people 
participate equally, have a voice in the planning of water sanitation facilities, and receive equal 
benefits from the project, an ethnic minority development plan (EMDP) will be prepared for each 
subproject in areas where more than 50% of the population is from ethnic minorities. An ethnic 
minority  development  framework  is  included  in  the  project  for  the  preparation  of  EMDPs. 
Subprojects where less than 50% of the population is from ethnic minorities will include actions 
specifically targeted at such groups in the subproject design. For the subproject in To Vieng 
commune of Tay Giang District in Quang Nam Province, an EMDP has been prepared. The 
summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 10.

78.  Gender impacts. Women provide most of the labor in the collection and use of water. 
They are also usually responsible for taking care of sick family members. Access to improved 
water services and sanitation facilities will have a positive impact on family health and will allow 
women to spend more time on productive activities. The CBA of the project will provide an 
opportunity for women to participate in planning water and sanitation services. Women's active 
involvement in planning community water and sanitation facilities will increase their voice in 
community affairs.  Specific attention will be given to targeting women in implementing the IEC 
for behavioral change. The capacity of VWU will be developed to mobilize the community to 
create demand for water and sanitation services, and to implement IEC. The WSCCs and their 
working groups will be at least 40% women, and will include representatives from the VWUs, 
HSPs, and the communities. In addition, at least 50% of the HSPs will be women. A project- 
specific gender strategy will ensure women's participation in planning and implementation of 
water and sanitation facilities and in building the capacity of the women's union, and staff of the 
PPMU to secure the active involvement of women in the project activities. The summary gender 
analysis and action plan is in Appendix 11. 
 
79.  Land acquisition and resettlement. The main resettlement impacts created by the 
project will be the permanent loss of land for the construction of water supply plants and minor 
damage to structures, crops and trees and the temporary loss or disruption of the use of land 
caused by the construction of pipelines. Most permanent acquisition will be limited to land that is 
publicly owned and reserved for infrastructure purposes, although some permanent acquisition 
will be required along the pipeline route where it traverses private agricultural land. Where the 
public land is currently used for other purposes, the users of the land will be offered alternative 
land so they are no worse off as a result of the project. 
 
80.  The six PPCs will be responsible for resettlement plan preparation and implementation. 
The resettlement plans for the six core subprojects will need to be updated once the final 
designs have been completed. Upon completion of detailed designs, a detailed measurement 
survey will be completed, which will confirm the number of affected people and the extent of 
impact. Compensation rates will be updated for all categories of lost assets and allowances 
based on replacement cost surveys undertaken at that time. The updating of resettlement plans 
and the preparation of resettlement plans for other (as yet unidentified) subprojects will be 
undertaken by the project implementation consultant with the support of the respective PPCs.  
 
81.  A  resettlement  framework  has  been  prepared  to  address  the  other  subprojects  in 
accordance with ADB policy. The resettlement framework contains key components including a 
definition  of  the  cutoff  date,  an  entitlement  matrix,  the  process  for  preparation  of  future 
resettlement  plans,  minimum  requirements  for  surveys  (detailed  measurement  survey, 
socioeconomic  survey  and  replacement  cost  survey),  consultation,  grievance  redress  and 
disclosure  requirements,  controls  relating  to  vulnerability,  gender  and  ethnicity,  institutional 
arrangements, M&E requirements, and an implementation schedule. The summary resettlement 
plan and resettlement framework is in Appendix 12. 
 
82.  Environmental impacts. The environmental classification of the project is category B. 
Based  on  the  results of  the  initial  environmental  examinations  (IEEs),  the subprojects  are 
unlikely to cause significant adverse environmental impacts since they are intended to improve 
the quality of environment and living standards of rural communities in the subproject areas. 
Benefits include the increase in the number of houses connected to clean and reliable water 
supply  for  drinking  and  sanitation,  minimized  or  eliminated  flooding  and  stagnation  of 
wastewater, and improved personal sanitation. The potential adverse environmental impacts 
associated with design, construction and operation of the subprojects will be small and localized 
and  can  be  readily  mitigated  through  proper  engineering  design  and  implementation  of

19 
mitigation and monitoring measures identified in the IEEs. An environmental assessment and 
review framework (EARF) has been prepared for future subprojects. 
 
83.  Economic benefits. Six sample subprojects were selected for the feasibility study. The 
economic internal rates of return (EIRRs) for the pilot subprojects range from 13.4% in Quang 
Nam to 23.0% in Nghe An. These projections suggest that all six subprojects examined are 
economically viable, since their EIRRs are all well above the economic opportunity cost of 
capital of 12% for the benefits that have been quantified. 
 
84.  Major quantifiable benefits attributable to the project include: (i) nonincremental benefits 
(water supplied by the project will replace most of the water sources currently used by the 
households);  (ii)  incremental  benefits  (beneficiaries’  willingness  to  pay  for  improved  and 
expanded water services and their consequent increase in water consumption); (iii) user cost 
savings (as a result of lower costs for water storage and boiling and filtration); and (iv) time 
savings in the collection of water. The economic costs of the pilot subprojects include capital 
costs (including land acquisition and resettlement, and environmental mitigation and monitoring 
costs) and O&M costs (including the costs of replacing depreciated equipment). 
 
85.  Financial management capacity. The financial management capability of NCERWASS 
is adequate to implement the project. Training in ADB disbursement procedures will be provided 
by the project. The financial management capacity of PCERWASS varies, but in general needs 
strengthening.  The  project  implementation  consultants  will  review  the  financial  information 
systems  and  procedures  of  PCERWASS  and  propose  modifications.  The  consultants  will  
(i) draft terms of reference for external auditors, (ii) prepare a financial management plan,  
(iii)  assist  in  implementing  this  plan,  (iv)  prepare  a  training  program,  and  (v)  develop  a 
methodology for periodic reviews of the water supply tariff. The PPMU staff will be trained in 
ADB loan processing and policies and related procedures for procurement and disbursement. 
 
86.  Risks  and  mitigation  measures.  The  following  are  potential  risks  for  the  project:  
(i)  poor  households  may  not  be  able  to  afford  water  supply  tariffs  at  full  cost  recovery;  
(ii) local government agencies may be unable to implement CBA and the gender strategy or 
may  resist  doing  so;  (iii)  implementation  of  IEC  activities  may  take  a  traditional  top-down 
approach instead of intensive community mobilization; (iv) women, poor people, and members 
of ethnic minorities may be marginalized in decision making and the planning of water and 
sanitation facilities at the community level; (v) beneficiaries may not adopt hygienic behavior, 
which may reduce some of the benefits of the project; and (vi) water supply facilities may not be 
sustainable because of low water tariffs and improper O&M. 
 
87.  To mitigate these risks, communities will be involved in the preparation, implementation, 
and monitoring of water supply works, so facilities are appropriate to the community needs. 
Individual households will be targeted to raise awareness of the importance of hygiene for family 
health and so they can contribute labor and local materials for building latrines. Training will be 
provided  to  local  governmental  agencies,  community  facilitators,  and  commune  water  and 
sanitation  committees  so  they  can  develop  a  better  understanding  of  the  effectiveness  of 
community  mobilization  for  implementing  IEC  CBA,  and  the  EMDP,  for  planning,  and  for 
ensuring  the  equal  participation  of  men  and  women  in  decision  making  for  community 
investments in water and sanitation. Monitoring indicators that are disaggregated by poverty, 
ethnicity,  and  gender  will  be  included  in  the  project  monitoring  system.  The  community 
facilitators will be trained in community mobilization and implementation of IEC and to monitor 
hygienic behavior. The appropriateness and affordability of the water supply systems will be 
assessed during project implementation and discussed with the communities, following the

CBA. The project will support the PPCs to set water tariffs to cover operation, maintenance and 
depreciation costs, and to train operators to run the systems efficiently.

reviewed and approved the revolving fund implementation guidelines.

the establishment of these committees and ensure their composition as agreed

continued existence and effective functioning beyond the project period.

(d) at least 50% of the HSPs are female, (e) formation of one men and one

RURAL WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Government Strategy 
 
1.  National rural water supply and sanitation strategy. The National Rural Clean Water 
Supply and Sanitation Strategy to 20201 was developed by the Ministry of Construction and the 
Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD). The strategy was approved by the 
Prime Minister on 25 August 2000.2 
  
2.  In  developing  the  strategy,  the  importance  and  context  of  rural  water  supply  and 
sanitation (RWSS) were recognized: 75% of the national population is rural and predominantly 
poor,  and  better  RWSS  is  needed  to  achieve  better  public  health,  living  conditions,  and 
environment. As a result, RWSS was made one of seven national target programs in 2000. At 
the time, only 30% of the population had access to water that met basic hygiene criteria, and 
only 20% of rural households had hygienic latrines. Investment in RWSS was only 10% of the 
amount needed, understanding of good hygienic practices was low, and use of fresh excreta as 
fertilizer was common. In addition, RWSS programs were fragmented, with little coordination 
among  ministries  and  departments  and  a  weak  legislative  environment  with  respect  to 
regulations and guidelines for the management of RWSS.   
 
3.  The strategy sets ambitious targets for physical infrastructure, 100% coverage for both 
clean water supply and hygienic latrines by 2020, but without identifying the specific projects, 
total investments, or sources of funds that might be required to achieve these objectives.  
 
4.  Evaluation of Rural Water Supply and Sanitation National Target Program I (2001–
2005). The RWSS strategy was implemented over the period 2001–2005 as a national target 
program (NTP I). At the conclusion of RWSS NTP I, a sector status report was developed by a 
government–partner  organization  review  team  and  issued  in  January  2005.  The  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) was part of the team. The report represents the most comprehensive 
effort seen to date to evaluate RWSS at the national level. In particular, it places RWSS within 
the perspective of the rapid economic development of Viet Nam in recent years.  
 
5.  The  evaluation  of  NTP  I  revealed  that  progress  had  been  made:  (i)  water  supply 
coverage  was  extended  to  23  million  people;  (ii)  3.7  million  more  households were  using 
hygienic latrines; (iii) a newly introduced sanitation campaign led to improvements in hygienic 
practices; (iv) the number of schools, commune health clinics, and rural markets with water 
supply  and  sanitation  facilities  increased;  (v)  funding  sources  were  diversified  (43%  from 
beneficiaries, 22% from central budget, 16% from international partner organizations, and 19% 
from other sources); and (vi) legal documents and guidelines were prepared to encourage 
different  economic  sectors  to  invest  in  the  sector  and  to  stimulate  a  diversification  of 
management models. 
 
6.  It was also concluded that the water supply coverage targets for 2010 and 2020 are 
likely to be met provided existing efforts were maintained. However, there was little prospect of 
meeting the sanitation targets. Because households have had to pay to build their own latrines, 
the poor lag far behind better-off households in coverage rates. The review also stressed the 
importance  of  targeting  government  and  partner  organization  support  at  the  poorest

B.  Sector Responsibilities and Limitations 
 
12.  The institutional structure of the RWSS is complex. There are a number of different 
agencies and programs in addition to the RWSS NTP II that are part of national efforts to 
achieve RWSS coverage and poverty targets. Decentralization means that provinces have 
substantial  autonomy  with  regard  to  budgets  and  responsibility  for  planning  and  activity 
implementation.  
 
13.  MARD  is  the  lead  agency  for  RWSS.  It  has  delegated  the  responsibility  for 
implementation of programs financed by partner organizations to the National Center for Rural 
Water  Supply  and  Sanitation  (NCERWASS).  The  government-funded  NTP  II  program  is 
administered by the national standing office based in the Department of Water Resources 
Management in MARD.  
 
14.  In  addition  to  managing  the  implementation  of  programs  financed  by  partner 
organizations, including those by ADB, the World Bank, and Japan International Cooperation 
Agency  (JICA),  NCERWASS  undertakes  various  support  activities.  These  include: 
implementation of a monitoring and evaluation system for RWSS; development of management 
models  for  piped  water  systems  (e.g.,  user  groups,  cooperatives,  and  public  utilities); 
preparation of introductory material on RWSS technologies; and development of operation and 
maintenance guidelines for various types of water supply systems. 
 
15.  The Ministry of Finance is responsible for recurrent budget allocations to NTPs, financial 
controls,  and  release  of  funds  to  provinces.  The  Ministry  of  Planning  and  Investments  in 
consultation with the Ministry of Finance proposes budget allocations for approval by the Prime 
Minister and the National Assembly.  
 
16.  The Ministry of Health is responsible for developing awareness on hygiene and health 
and for setting and monitoring water quality standards. The Ministry of Education and Training is 
responsible for health and hygiene programs in schools. Responsibilities are delegated to the 
provincial departments of these ministries: departments of health and departments of education 
and training.

Rural and Clean Water and Environmental Sanitation in developing information, education and 
communication materials.  
 
3.  The World Bank supports the sector primarily through the Red River Delta Water Supply 
and Sanitation Project, focusing on piped water supply schemes following demand-responsive 
approach and principles of the national RWSS strategy.  
 
4.  The two main partner organizations are Danida and AusAID, who, with support of the 
Netherlands, will provide budget support for the implementation of the National Target Plan II. In 
addition,  they  are  providing  technical  assistance  to  Ministry  of  Agriculture  and  Rural 
Development (MARD) to prepare legislation and technical guidelines.  
 
5.  JICA provides assistance for groundwater resource development and the European 
Union supports RWSS through integrated rural development projects. 
 
6.  Over  40  nongovernment  organizations  (NGO)  are  active  in  the  sector  in  about  40 
provinces, more so in water than sanitation. This is often as an element of more broadly based 
development support than through focused projects. NGOs have been successful in fostering 
community participation and demand-responsive approaches, but because of their small-scale 
and local focus, lessons have only been mainstreamed into national programs to a limited 
degree. 
 
B.  Institutional Arrangements and Processes for Development Coordination  
 
7.  The joint government-donor review of National Target Plan I concluded that there is a 
lack of coordination among the government, partner organizations, and NGOs. In 2006 MARD 
and several partner organizations, including the Asian Development Bank (ADB), established 
the Rural Water Supply and Sanitation Partnership (RWSSP). The objective of the partnership 
is to maximize the efficiency of resource utilization within the sector through collaborations that 
would harmonize the many policies and programs in existence. The partnership has regular 
meetings to discuss the development progress of the sector in general and to discuss regulatory 
and technical issues. It also provides a forum for development partners to share lessons learned 
through the circulation of a bimonthly newsletter.  
 
8.  The RWSSP is guided by a steering committee consisting of representatives of the 
various relevant ministries, such as MARD, Ministry of Construction, Ministry of Health, and 
Ministry of Education and Training. The daily activities are implemented by a coordinating unit,

34  Appendix 3 
established within MARD and through specific technical working groups. The partnership has 
and active website, holds regular meetings and produces a bi-monthly newsletter. 
 
9.  One of the principal tasks before the RWSSP is to help formulate the Unified Sanitation 
Sector Strategy and Action Plan, since sanitation (rural and urban) has been identified as a 
priority issue in Viet Nam. The Water and Sanitation Program is one of the lead organizations in 
the  consultative  team  responsible  for  engaging  with  the  relevant  government  agencies 
preparing the sanitation strategy. ADB, too, is participating in this endeavor. 
 
C.  Achievements, Issues and Recommendations  
 
10.  ADB's history of financing the water supply and sanitation sector in Viet Nam has mainly 
focused on urban areas. ADB's goals include sustainable environmental management and 
inclusive social development under its Strategy 2020.1  Its support for RWSS will help ADB 
achieve its goals of providing access to infrastructure by rural communities and improving living 
standards.  The proposed project will allow ADB to actively support the review of the national 
RWSS strategy, develop a capacity building strategy, and seek cooperation with development 
partners through the RWSSP. 
 
11.  In formulating the project, ADB has extensively consulted with the development partners 
through  formal  consultations  and  informal  consultations.  The  RWSSP  has  substantially 
contributed to discuss and align the various partner approaches.  
 
12.  A main issue to be discussed further is the issue of a possible sector wide approach, or 
budget support as provided by Danida, AusAID, and the Netherlands. Although this approach 
was  considered  for  this  project  as  well,  the  limited  implementation  capacity,  especially  at 
provincial level, was seen as a major risk. Also, the fiduciary risks were considered to be too 
high. 
 
13.  Through a continuous dialogue with partners and the government and based on the 
lessons learned of the development partners, this issue should be further explored and possibly 
adapted in future ADB intervention in the RWSS sector in Viet Nam.

SUBPROJECT SELECTION CRITERIA AND PROCEDURES 
 
1.  Selection of subprojects. The project will start with orientation workshops in the project 
provinces. These will enable district governments to introduce the project, its objectives and the 
eligibility criteria for subproject selection. Following these workshops, districts can submit their 
proposed subprojects to the provincial project management unit (PPMUs). 
 
2.  In order for subprojects to be eligible, they have to demonstrate that piped water supply 
systems with a central water source are the most economical way of supplying water in the 
subproject areas and that they comply with the following criteria.  
  
(i)  Communes have relatively high population densities. Human and animal waste 
disposal are likely to contaminate shallow ground water layer. 
(ii)  Shallow groundwater layers are polluted, making the water unfit for consumption 
or requiring extensive treatment. Pollutants include salinity, fluoride, arsenic, and 
iron.  
(iii)  Suitable  readily  accessible  drinking  water  sources  are  scarce.  The  shallow 
groundwater or nearby surface water sources have too little yield in the dry 
season to sustain the requirements of the population, leading to a drying up of 
shallow groundwater wells, surface streams, and springs. 
 
3.  The existence of one or a combination of these situations will justify the exploitation of 
raw water sourced from deep groundwater layers, or located outside the subproject area, and of 
a central water treatment facility.  
 
4.  Once a shortlist of subprojects has been established, the potential subprojects will be 
prioritized based on the following criteria and weighting: 
(i)  poverty ratio (40%), 
(ii)  ethnic minority ratio (30%), and 
(iii)  RWSS coverage ratios (30%). 
 
5.  The highest ranked subprojects with similar final scores will be reviewed and the final 
ranking will be based on the per capita investment costs1 and the readiness for implementation. 
The six sample subprojects covered by the project preparatory technical assistance 2 have been 
given the highest priority on the shortlist, since they comply with the eligibility criteria and are in 
an advanced stage of readiness. 
 
6.  Approval of subprojects. Following the preparation of the shortlist, final approval of 
subprojects by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will be based on a subproject appraisal 
report that includes (i) a feasibility study; (ii) financial and economic analysis; (iii) a commitment 
letter from the provincial people’s committee (PPC) to ensure the financial sustainability of the 
water supply system; (iv) required safeguard documents on environment, resettlement, and 
ethnic  minorities;  (v)  a  community-based  approach  and  information,  education,  and 
communication (CBA-IEC) plan; (vi) an agreement between the PPMU and Subproject CPCs on 
the level of customers' contribution and payment mechanism for the water supply works; and 
(vii)  a  baseline  survey  covering  socioeconomic,  health,  and  water  supply  and  sanitation 
coverage data.

A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
The framework for all poverty reduction activities in Viet Nam is the Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and 
Growth Strategy (CPRGS), which recognizes that access to clean and safe water and sanitary toilets is a 
precondition for poverty reduction, specifically for Viet Nam's rural population. Viet Nam’s average gross 
domestic product growth of 7.8% per year between 2002 and 2007 reduced the poverty rate from 28.9% to 
16.0%, but it did not close the gap between urban and rural areas. The poverty rate in rural areas (where 72% 
of the people live) is still 20.4%. In targeting rural areas this project will benefit populations with high levels of 
poverty. The project will facilitate poor households' access to project benefits by providing them with water 
connections.  
 
The project will improve the health and welfare of household beneficiaries, hasten the reduction of rural 
poverty, and help to close urban–rural income gap. The provision of clean water will improve the quantity and 
quality of marketable production, particularly from arable crops, livestock husbandry and fishing, which are the 
primary income sources of poorer households. The project responds to the key challenges identified in the 
ADB's country strategy and program, 2007−2010:a  to promote socially equitable and balanced development, 
sustainable environmental management, and institutional capacity strengthening. It likewise supports the 
major targets of Viet Nam’s Socio-Economic Development Plan, 2006−2010b and the Vietnamese Millennium 
Development Goals (MDG). These include reducing poverty to 10%–11%, creating 8 million new jobs and 
facilitating the adoption of clean technologies and pollution minimization facilities. Providing clean water will 
reduce the need to boil water for consumption, thereby reducing the demand for firewood. This will contribute 
to the government target of increasing forest cover.

1. Key Issues 
 
One reason for the comparatively higher poverty in rural areas is the slow growth of agriculture, which is still 
the backbone of the rural economy. Agriculture, forestry and fisheries have 55% of the employed population 
but grew by only 3.8% per year between 2001 and 2005. In contrast, industry grew by 10.2% and services by

having a higher poverty rate. It also varies among ethnic groups within provinces, with minority groups being 
much poorer. The poverty rate among ethnic minorities was estimated to be 60% in 2005. These groups 
generally live in rural areas and are more dependent of agriculture than the rest of the population.  
 
A total of 24 subprojects in 30 communes in six provinces will be selected. They cover a range of activities

The poverty rate in the To Vieng is 60%.

efficiency of their production and business operations. Activities to achieve this target include reviewing and

II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 
Rural water supply and sanitation is a particularly important concern in Viet Nam as some 38% of the rural 
population still lacks access to piped drinking water. Even where piped water is available, it often does not 
meet safety standards. Pollution from salinity intrusion, livestock waste, commercial waste, and agricultural 
chemicals is increasingly endangers public health. Up to half the cases of communicable diseases in Viet 
Nam are related to poor water supply and sanitation. 
 
The  provinces  in  the  Central  Region  have  poverty  levels  that  are  higher  than  the  national  average; 
investments for water supply and sanitation by local governments are, therefore, limited. In the region, only 
10% to 15% of households are served by a private tap or public standpipe. About half of households obtain 
water from shallow dug wells, which are easily susceptible to bacterial contamination and saline intrusion, and 
20%–25% of people in the central region receive water from relatively expensive private deep wells. The 
region suffers from water shortages in the dry season and contaminated supplies from flooding of dug wells in 
the wet season. Groundwater is heavily exploited for the irrigation of cash crops, resulting in frequent water 
shortages. Shallow groundwater contains high levels of salinity, turbidity, hardness, fluoride, iron, manganese, 
aluminum, and pollution from humans, industry, and livestock. Surface water is often affected by turbidity, 
organic matter, and pollution by surface runoff that contains microorganisms and agricultural chemicals. River 
water in the lower reaches is polluted by industry and settlements upstream. As a result, many rural 
households, particularly those with ethnic minority populations, have little choice on their source of drinking 
water and they are sometimes forced to buy water from vendors or fetch water from long distances at high 
costs. Poor households have to use highly polluted water for many of their daily water needs. 
 
The low per capita consumption and low population density in remote areas makes attaching the communes 
to regional water supply services a financially unattractive proposition. However, most of these communities 
have good potential to establish a local water supply service that can be developed to meet local demand for 
clean water.   
 
In the project areas, people complain about the poor quality of available water supplies. Complaints range 
from a bad smell to high particle content. Households in three project provinces also report an annual water 
shortage. Sanitation facilities vary among communes and 70%–90% of households use pit latrines. Waste 
water and solid wastes are generally disposed of by being used as fertilizer on arable land or are tipped, 
untreated, into the nearest river or pond.  Only 25% of people in the project area reported washing their hands 
after using toilets.  Cholera, diarrhea, malaria, dengue fever, parasitic worms, skin diseases, and child 
malnutrition are common in the project area. Sporadic outbreaks of cholera and other water-associated 
diseases within the project areas lead to the loss of many days work and absence from school. In focus group 
discussions in the core subprojects, 46% of respondents reported that children could not attend schools 
sometimes because of water related sickness. A major benefit of choosing the water supply and sanitation 
services sector is that it will improve community health. As a result it will increase the supply of labor available 
for economic development activities and reduce the school time lost by children due to sickness.  
Providing opportunities for communities to access improved services may not automatically result in their 
adoption. The IEC campaign can play a significant role in raising awareness, changing hygiene behavior, and 
motivating people to pay for monthly water bills. The Quang Nam project area is being promoted as a model 
village. A principal benefit of living here is that each house was supplied with a flush toilet. As a consequence, 
the number of work and/or school days lost to sickness is now insignificant. Emphasis will be given to 
planning an effective IEC implementation plan for the project.
